title: U.S. Stocks Mixed After Fed Comments; Major cryptocurrencies stabilize with bitcoin trading around $16,600
text:
Stocks had gained in recent days on hopes that the Fed may not have to tighten financial conditions much more after U.S. inflation in October came in below economists' estimates. The Fed's quest to tame inflation this year has dragged down stocks, bonds and commodities.

"Just because there might be peak inflation, just because the Fed slows down, that doesn't actually mean that starts a new bull market because the recession risk still runs relatively high for next year," said Keith Lerner, co-chief investment officer at Truist Advisory Services Inc. Mr. Lerner said stocks don't always rally when the Fed is cutting rates, pointing to the S&P 500's performance in 2000.

Some of last week's excitement cooled down to start the week. Fed Chairwoman Lael Brainard on Monday said recent inflation data offered some signs of reassurance that price pressures were no longer broadening and that the central bank could soon slow the pace of interest-rate rises.

That overshadowed comments from Fed governor Christopher Waller over the weekend, who said policy makers still had "a ways to go" and would like to see more similar data points before easing its foot off the brake.

"We should get that one data point is not a trend, we shouldn't get carried away. If the market is expecting a pivot on the back of this, I'm afraid we're going to be disappointed," said Arun Sai, a multiasset strategist at Pictet Asset Management. "Now the focus should shift to the real economy and whether it can digest what has already happened" in terms of interest-rate increases.

The yield on the benchmark 10-year Treasury note edged up to 3.871% from 3.828% at last week's close.

"We don't have the Fed put," said Lori Van Dusen, chief executive at LVW Advisors in Rochester, N.Y. Ms. Van Dusen said that rallies like last week's are common in bear markets. She is recommending investors to stick to buying high-quality companies with growing cash flows since she said she believes the Fed will stay focused on their fight to tame inflation regardless of what happens to stocks.

Tesla shares declined 0.5%. Chief Executive Elon Musk said he has too much work to juggle after the Twitter takeover and that he was running Tesla's operations "with great difficulty."

Hasbro fell 8.8%, on pace for the largest percentage decrease since October 2020. The maker of Monopoly board games and My Little Pony dolls fell after Bank of America analysts double downgraded to underperform from buy rating, saying that the company is overproducing Magic: The Gathering card game.

Major retailers including Walmart and Home Depot are due to report earnings Tuesday.

Bitcoin traded around $16,600 in morning trading. Ether, the second most-popular cryptocurrency inched up to trade around $1,250.

"The immediate storm following the collapse of the huge exchange FTX has subsided," said Susannah Streeter, a market analyst at Hargreaves Lansdown. "This whole debacle also comes with a sense of relief that the deep skepticism among regulators about crypto's stability has ringfenced larger, more established financial institutions from contagion."

Overseas, Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index jumped 1.7% led by property stocks on reports that Beijing officials signed off on sweeping measuresto support the real-estate sector. Country Garden and Longfor Group soared 46% and 16%, respectively.

Japan's Nikkei 225 slid 1.1%, weighed down by SoftBank's 13% drop. The investment company posted further losses and disappointed investors by not putting forward an expected share buyback.

The pan-continental Stoxx Europe 600 rose 0.1%.

â€”Hardika Singh contributed to this article.

Write to Anna Hirtenstein at anna.hirtenstein@wsj.com
